subject: Missing Worldcon
event:
I wish I was in Yokohama.

Yeah, yeah, I know.  I made the logical, adult, sensible decision, and stayed home to work on A DANCE WITH DRAGONS and my myriad other projects.  It wouldn't have made much sense for me to fly to Japan just for the con, not with the trip being as grueling and expensive as it is, and I certainly couldn't afford to take off the month or six weeks it would have required for me to do worldcon, and make promotional appearances in Japan, Korea, and China as well, as my various Asian publishers wanted.  And no matter how long or short the trip was, the mails and emails and bills and deadlines would have piled up monstrously in my absence, and I would have returned to find myself buried, and it would have taken another two weeks just to dig myself out, and I can't afford that time, I really can't.

I know all that.

All the same, not being at worldcon is killing me.  I was okay at first, when I just knew in a kind of abstract way that the con was going on, but now con reports and pictures are starting to show up on various blogs and listservs that I frequent, and every time I read one it bums me out a little more.  Maybe if everyone was writing, "this is the worst damned convention in worldcon history," and "Japan is unbearable," I would feel a little better about staying home, but that's not what they are writing at all.

Today the Hugo results came in, salt in the wound.  Not only have I missed worldcon and the chance to visit Japan, but I have missed the Hugoes for the first time in twenty-one years.  

And THEN I hear that Montreal has won the 2009 worldcon over Kansas City.  Sucks.  

Ah, what can I say...

comments.article:
(Hi! I don't think I've commented on your blog before. I'd say I'm a big fan, except I haven't read the books yet - they're on the Booklover's Big List Of Unread Books, somewhere near the top, for after I've done Jack Whyte's Dream of Eagles books, which I nearly have - but I really enjoy the blog.)

I wanted to say that I am thrilled that Montreal has won Worldcon 2009 - partly because it means I'll get to go with one of the best teachers I've ever had, who took me to my first Worldcon ever, and whose health no longer allows her to travel, partly because it's a way to visit my family, but mostly because, even though I no longer live there, I love the place I grew up and am always thrilled that more people will have a chance to discover just how wonderful it is. I also wanted to offer a guided tour in 2009, if you like; I'm a good tour guide and local history enthusiast.

On the other hand, it would be neat to go to Kansas City. I've never been there, and if it had won, the theme of Worldcon 2010 could have been the Wizard of Oz - "Not In Kansas Anymore!"

I'd just like to point out Kansas City is in Missouri.
Just one of those things.

I am pretty emo I am not there too - the reports look like so much fun. Also bummed KC didn't win the bid. :(

comments.article: On the plus side, Montreal has poutine.

And smoked meat sandwiches from Schwartz's, tarte au sucre from Maam Bolduc, duck confit from P'tit Plateau, oysters at Joe Beef, the famous bologna and salami sandwiches at Wilensky's served with a real egg cream...

We're really a heart attack on a plate up here, but damn it tastes good.
Having been to Kansas City, I don't understand the draw.  Montreal, at least, would seem to have something going for it.  I'm just saying.

I hear Montreal is a great city. That's swell. I look forward to visiting.

The worldcon is another matter. Worldcons are not supposed to be decided simply on who has the grooviest city. Things like the competence of the committee, the facilities, and the dates are supposed to enter the equation, and on all those counts the KC bid was vastly superior.

Miss you George. :(

You and I should take George to a football game or something.  That'd be way better than having a bunch of crazy middle school girls running up to George in the street, saying "Tonight it is probably rain, the green notebook is more small than the funny radio!" and asking if they can touch his beard.

Worldcon last year must have been amazing. Some of my friends went and ended up winning Best-in-Show in the costume competition. So they told some very exciting stories.

I was actually commenting because I was wondering if you accept emails from fans. Your email is on your site, but I didn't know if actual fan-question emails were accepted. I vaguely recall you mentioning you take emails at your book signing in San Diego last year, but I can't remember for sure, so I wanted to ask as not to clutter your inbox with irritating emails. Thank you.

I get hundreds of fan mails.

I read them all. I reply to very few. There just isn't time. I don't tend to answer questions about the books. Those I refer to the Westeros board, where there are many people who can answer them just as well as I could.

I do sometimes reply with a simple "you're welcome" to the "thank you" mails.
I have some form responses I have used from time to time. I try to give special attention to guys writing from Iraq. There are a surprising number of those. Sometimes a letter is especially funny, or asks a question I have never heard before, or otherwise piques my interest, and I reply. Even with those, however, it happens less and less frequently.

I would love to be able to answer every fan mail I receive, as I did back in the 70s. But in the 70s, I was lucky if I got three fan letters a year.

comments.article:
I guess it's only natural for you to feel that way but if you manage to advance ADWD during that time in a significant way, won't you be then pleased that you did? ;)

~Syn

Didn't you hear? There was a huge earthquake, followed by a tidal wave, followed by a huge reptile rampaging through the city the con is in, and then to top it all off the name badges were contaminated with bacteria, so everyone who attended ended up with necrotizing fasciitis.

There is no need to look up these facts to verify them. Just take my word for it, and be glad that you stayed home. We are!
There was a typhoon, but it was a couple of days after the con.

It does sound like it was a terrific time, and were Japan a few thousand miles closer Linda and I might have considered it. We've only gone to two Worldcons, though, so it doesn't sting remotely as much as it must do so for you.

That said, I have to admit that while our heads were for the KC bid, our hearts were kind of hoping for Montreal. Anaheim was a fun convention, but not as much so as Glasgow for us, and that had everything to do with the fact that there was really nothing worthwhile to see (or eat) around the convention center. In Glasgow, Linda and I tramped all around the city center and ate some truly marvellous food (shout outs to Mr. Singh's -- we ate there twice, even -- and Chokoku, in particular), and that was pretty memorable for us. Montreal sounds like it can be a similar experience.

We didn't stay at the official convention hotels the first two times, and are considering renting an apartment for the week anyways, so the lack of hotels directly connected to the Congress isn't too much of a problem for us, anyways, especially as Montreal appears to be quite well-served with its public transporation. Hopefully they'll make good arrangements with the hotels in the area.

Montreal has excellent public transportation, including the metro (underground) and a fleet of buses.  It's also a very walkable city, and if you get too tired of walking, there are taxis all over the place - it's the most cab-friendly place I've ever lived.  Also, I don't know what hotel the WorldCon will be in, but many hotels downtown are linked by the "underground city," a warren of malls and corridors and shops and foodcourts under a goodly part of the downtown core.  You can come here and never actually go outside (a definite plus when it's -35C or +35C, not uncommon occurrences in winter and summer here)!

I felt the same way two years ago when the Worldcon was in Glasgow, one of the few times it was near enough to me to actually be able to go --and then I had a bit of a misfortune and the funds just weren't there and it was very hard the week the con was actually on, especially seeing the reports later.

Sorry you missed the con, George.  But we are so glad you are dedicated to pleasing us book hounds.  I agree about Worldcon in Canada . . . the place is way too expensive . . . economy should come into play for us poor folk who can't afford trips to Japan and the exorbitant overhead of Canada.  When you buy a pack of smokes in Canada, you're actually paying to have some guy's spleen removed (some Canadian guy) . . . why should I have to pay for that when I don't live there?
A hint from a Canadian who hosts visitors from elsewhere on a fairly regular basis: you can keep your receipts and file for a refund of the taxes when you leave. ;)

I started readin your books when I was really really depressed, even suicidal actually, and they provided a sanctuary from the anxiety that overwhelmed me from time to time. Even though I'm feeling loads better (thank god!) I'm still really looking forward to DwD. So, I love you for staying home working, even if you are really missing out. But you know what? Im guessing that this book is really hanging like a shadow over your head by now, think of the relief when it's finally done! And with that in mind, I don't think you'd been able to enjoy Japan anyway...

I'm proud of you. Keep up the good work, even if life sucks at the moment.
Anna
